content:
It's possible that people/companies interested in AI and category theory will attend this workshop on machine learning and type theory... and if you're interested, you should fill out this form:

https://twitter.com/TaliaRinger/status/1409302822940598272

Interested in a machine learning and type theory workshop? Please fill this form out so that I can gauge interest and collect ideas! https://forms.gle/oWUgW67CCChZfs6j8

- Talia Ringer (@TaliaRinger)
It frustrates me that AI is synonymous with machine learning. I am deeply interested in AI but not remotely interested in machine learning.
I think there will eventually be a (partial) return to more logical approaches to AI. For example, the drive towards ‘explained AI’ now is pushing researchers in this direction.
I agree though. Data cleaning and curve fitting can only be so interesting.

Youse have no appreciation for just how much progress was made in 10 years through mostly deep reinforcement learning.... for example when I was an undergrad I knew for a fact that superhuman play in go would definitely never be achieved in my lifetime, this was a symbolic example of something that was unimaginably out of reach of any known method
And curve fitting can be quite interesting when your space has millions of dimensions. Probably the geometry of very high dimensional spaces isn't very well understood
It’s definitely interesting. It’s just that I agree with Morgan that it doesn’t deserve to be totally identified with the term ‘AI’.
It’s an approach to AI which works very well at the specific tasks it’s meant to address.

Yeah I have no doubts about the power of ML, it's more that AI research is (or at least should be) a lot more than its implementation in ML. Take this article, for example. While the GridWorld implementations are cute, taking an experimental approach seems hugely inefficient when thought experiments would have been enough to identify the pitfalls.

Morgan Rogers (he/him) said:

It frustrates me that AI is synonymous with machine learning. I am deeply interested in AI but not remotely interested in machine learning.

They are not synonymous but if you stand far enough they are too close to be distinguishable. As you approach them you quickly realize they're separate. So I think it's a function of who is using the term, and where they stand.
@Matteo Capucci (he/him) you can see how that's unfortunate for someone like me who wants to get into AI research without having to program neural networks. :sweat_smile:
Well, I guess if you want to do any kind of AI at research level you'd better know at least the landscape of machine learning, even if you're not doing research in it

Just my 2cents: You may consider topological data analysis to be part of AI as well. It's not directly AI, but very closely related: In practice, you cannot feed raw data to ML algorithms, you need to clean the data up and it is a very time consuming effort. So data analysis/extraction techniques that allow to perform these operations automatically are of great interest for AI researchers.

That reminds me of something an executive at my former employer said – many self-identifying data scientists / ML engineers are mostly just doing data cleansing. Perhaps we might call them data janitors instead.

@Jules Hedges I took a course in deep learning, so I know the theory, and I'm aware of the big stories in ML even if I don't make an active effort to follow them, because they always manage to make a splash.
@Fabrizio Genovese that's also cool, but still not what I'm interested in.
Maybe it would be useful for me to actually say what I am interested in! Alignment and safety problems in AI aren't going to be solved by making learners more efficient or polishing their datasets. Some of the most important questions in AI are essentially philosophical in nature, and that's where I want to be contributing.
Oh. Then you want to do the hard stuff

I guess there's very little work there atm, especially because the incremental contributions in ML are giving huge returns in terms of applications. When it's like this funding agencies and companies start chasing the low hanging fruits and are less interested in basic/foundational research
In any case it's a field that deserves attention. I just don't know how popular it will be in the next few years.

Morgan Rogers (he/him) said:

Maybe it would be useful for me to actually say what I am interested in! Alignment and safety problems in AI aren't going to be solved by making learners more efficient or polishing their datasets.

maybe I can join in to say that in my opinion "Alignment and safety problems in AI " do need work to IMPROVE their datasets completely. they are unfair, biased, racist, sexist, privacy-invading, status-quo reinforcing. this (like climate change) is not a problem for the future, it's a problem now! it's sending black and brown people to prison for crimes they didn't commit, it's not allowing people to open accounts, get mortgages, get jobs. Not a philosophical problem, but a problem at the interface of tech and social policy/social sciences. my two cents.
I agree on this, but this is not dependent on technical results, it's a social problem. When people build datasets, inevitably they put their biases in the datasets they build
Probably one possible way to go would be by having sociologists or other qualified people contributing in the building process.

Surely those problems exist because people ploughed into applying ML without examining the philosophical consequences ahead of time.
Valeria de Paiva said:

Not a philosophical problem, but a problem at the interface of tech and social policy/social sciences. my two cents.

I resent the implication that "philosophical" means 'esoteric' here, that's certainly not what it means to me. These are problems of ethics (which falls under philosophy!), and precise, applicable answers to these questions will make the difference that you're looking for. The fact that you're so unimpressed with the practice of philosophy that you dismiss it out of hand speaks to the sore need for such work to be done.
I was giving for granted that you wanted to work in AI on the mathematical side of things tho, are you referring to pure philosophy instead?

In any case, the very same fact that ML is reaching such important results by essentially heuristic means is philosophically interesting. Indeed, the idea of science as a completely formal thing is quite recent: We used to build entire cathedrals, pyramids and tons of other amazing stuff purely heuristically. Architects back then had no clue about what a tensor of inertia was, and still... This is to say that I am not necessarily a fan of the motto "ML people have no clue about why their stuff works." I think they have, it's just that their intuition does not respect what we people in hard sciences usually mean when we say that we know something.

Fabrizio Genovese said:

I was giving for granted that you wanted to work in AI on the mathematical side of things tho, are you referring to pure philosophy instead?

People brought maths into philosophy through the practice of logic; I expect to be leveraging my mathematical background in the process, but ultimately yes, I want to do what for now is considered "pure" philosophy. Hopefully also making it formal so that other mathematicians and computer scientists can attack it alongside me.
Maybe you already know this, but it sounds like the kind of thing the Machine Intelligence Research Institute does.

I was getting career advice on their Discord server today, as it happens! They gave me the impression that if I want to work in Europe (UK excluded) then my best bet is to apply for funding to do independent research. I have some concerns that that's a risky career move for a young researcher, so I'm still looking for more structured alternatives, but I may eventually do that.
I am an independent researcher, so AMA if you want to.
(At this precise time actually I am not, but I basically am, it's a bit hard to explain)
This topic was moved by Morgan Rogers (he/him) to #general: off-topic > AI isn't just ML
PlantingSpace is the company I'm working out, which is using category theory for a Bayesian learning system.
Oh cool, so you also work with Alessandro?
The redhead guy that does egraphs in Julia, I don't remember his surname unfortunately

Fabrizio Genovese said:

The redhead guy that does egraphs in Julia, I don't remember his surname unfortunately

Cheli
